app_summary: A social network with unidirectional follow relationships, implemented with loosely-coupled microservices, communicating with each other via Thrift RPCs. Supported Operations: Create text post (optional media: image, video, shortened URL, user tag), Read post, Read entire user timeline, Receive recommendations on which users to follow, Search database for user or post, Register/Login using user credentials, Follow/Unfollow user

symptoms.potential_symptom: Orchestration/service recursion or circular RPCs with associated errors
symptoms.evidence: All 5 slow traces (traceIDs: 00c527e12b772869, 022bd6014ff1ebb2, 00c783cfff619430, 022acab1165c736e, 0143c50f6ea50015) show the call sequence starting at nginx-thrift -> compose-post-service and returning to compose-post-service at the end of the trace (e.g., '... -> user-mention-service -> compose-post-service'). Each trace has has_error=true (error_message is empty/'; '), indicating compose-post-service is involved in failing traces and may be participating in a recursion or circular RPC pattern.

symptoms.potential_symptom: Duplicate invocations / retry loop of the mention handling component leading to errors
symptoms.evidence: In all 5 traces the user-mention-service appears twice within the same trace (examples: '... -> url-shorten-service -> user-mention-service -> url-shorten-service -> user-mention-service ...'). All traces have has_error=true (traceIDs listed above), indicating user-mention-service is repeatedly invoked in failing traces — consistent with retry loops, duplicated calls, or unintended re-entrancy.

symptoms.potential_symptom: Repeated calls to URL shortening service (possible retry/loop) associated with trace errors
symptoms.evidence: All 5 traces show url-shorten-service being called multiple times in the same request path (e.g., '... -> user-mention-service -> url-shorten-service -> user-mention-service ...'). Each trace has has_error=true (traceIDs: 00c527e12b772869, 022bd6014ff1ebb2, 00c783cfff619430, 022acab1165c736e, 0143c50f6ea50015) and an empty error_message ('; '), suggesting url-shorten-service is repeatedly invoked in failing traces and may be the target of retries or part of a call loop.

rca_tasks.investigation_goal: Epicenter check (domain: app/config): Hypothesis — compose-post-service is participating in a circular RPC because it advertises or forwards requests using a downstream endpoint that resolves back to itself (misconfigured callback/host or Thrift client pointing to wrong service), producing recursion and errors. Testable checks (two-sided where applicable): 1) kubectl describe/deployment for compose-post-service: inspect environment variables, configmaps, and command-line args for downstream hostnames/Thrift endpoints (look for entries referencing user-mention-service, url-shorten-service or any compose-post hostname). 2) kubectl logs (recent slow traces request-ids) from compose-post pods (post-storage-service list available) to confirm outgoing calls and whether the final return is routed back into compose-post. 3) Verify compose-post's Thrift client config (in pod filesystem or configmap) for callback URLs and timeouts. 4) Check compose-post pod CPU/memory and restart counts to rule out crash/restart loops. Relevant data deps: post-storage-service-5f4d46cbb9-8b98m, unique-id-service-fc74bdf74-v6shv, media-service-8486767bd-hx7ln, text-service-774b6cf48f-pfgwf, user-timeline-service-647bd67bfb-mfxdv, home-timeline-service-6bf55fbcd8-vkls2, user-service-5cf866746f-ck27p.

Connection check (compose-post-service <-> user-mention-service) (domain: config/communication): Hypothesis — compose-post's configured endpoint for user-mention does not match the user-mention Kubernetes Service (wrong host name, port, or Thrift service name) OR user-mention has a callback/backreference configured to compose-post causing a round trip. Two-sided explicit checks: 1) In compose-post pods/configmaps, locate the configured user-mention endpoint (hostname:port or Thrift service name) and note exact value. 2) kubectl get svc/deploy for user-mention-service: verify service name, ports, targetPort, and selectors. 3) Inspect user-mention deployment for any config/env that calls compose-post. 4) Correlate recent compose-post logs showing outgoing request to user-mention and user-mention logs showing incoming request origin to detect a callback into compose-post.

Connection check (compose-post-service <-> url-shorten-service) (domain: config/communication): Hypothesis — compose-post (directly or via mention) calls url-shorten-service using an incorrect service name/port or url-shorten-service is misconfigured to call back to compose-post, creating a loop. Two-sided explicit checks: 1) Inspect compose-post configmaps/deployment env for url-shorten endpoint and exact Thrift target. 2) kubectl get svc/deploy for url-shorten-service: verify port/name/targetPort and that DNS name matches compose-post's config. 3) Check url-shorten deployment for any outbound references to compose-post. 4) Correlate logs from both services for the same request-id to confirm a call/return path that loops.

Connection check (user-mention-service <-> url-shorten-service) (domain: app/config/communication): Hypothesis — user-mention and url-shorten are configured in a way that each can call the other (e.g., wrong endpoint or mis-wired callback), producing the observed repeated alternation in traces. Two-sided explicit checks: 1) Inspect user-mention config (env/configmap) for the url-shorten endpoint used. 2) Inspect url-shorten deployment/service for any configuration that calls user-mention (callbacks, webhooks or Thrift clients). 3) kubectl get svc for both services to verify ports/names. 4) Review logs on both sides for the same request-id showing the alternating sequence.

Service-level check (user-mention-service) (domain: app — duplicate invocations/retry loop): Hypothesis — user-mention lacks idempotency or is re-entrant because it does not validate unique request IDs, allowing duplicated processing when upstream retries; or it actively retries downstream calls without backoff causing duplicates. Testable checks: 1) kubectl logs for user-mention pods: search for repeated request IDs, duplicate processing markers, or internal retries. 2) Inspect user-mention code/config for idempotency keys, retry/backoff policy, and thrift client timeout/retry settings (in configmaps). 3) Examine metrics (request count vs success) and concurrent request limits; check for increase in retries/error counts corresponding to trace times.

Service-level check (url-shorten-service and its infra) (domain: dependency/config + infra): Hypothesis — url-shorten-service is intermittently failing or timing out (due to memcached or mongodb issues or misconfiguration), causing callers to retry; or its service config points to the wrong target producing loops. Testable checks: 1) kubectl logs for url-shorten pods for errors/timeouts around trace timestamps. 2) kubectl describe pods/services for url-shorten to confirm service ports and endpoints. 3) Check health of infra deps: kubectl get pods for url-shorten-memcached-566bf679b4-6skpr and url-shorten-mongodb-5466bc77c8-8nfvz; kubectl exec into their pods to run a basic memcached ping and mongo ping (or check container logs) to confirm availability and latencies. 4) Inspect url-shorten retry/backoff settings in configmaps and any cache-miss behaviour that triggers DB writes/reads leading to retries.

rca_analyses_list.diagnosis: compose-post-service is NOT participating in a circular RPC. Its configuration (service-config.json) correctly references downstream hostnames (user-mention-service, url-shorten-service, post-storage-service) and includes a self-entry for compose-post-service (expected). The observed errors are caused by post-storage-service being unreachable (Thrift connection refused), not by requests looping back into compose-post-service.
rca_analyses_list.reasoning:
1) ConfigMap (compose-post-service/service-config.json) shows downstream endpoints correctly set (e.g., "user-mention-service": {"addr": "user-mention-service"}, "url-shorten-service": {"addr": "url-shorten-service"}, and a self-entry for "compose-post-service" which is normal).
2) Pod logs from compose-post-service consistently show Thrift TSocket connect() failures to post-storage-service:9090 with "Connection refused" and client pool errors — indicating outgoing calls fail at that downstream service rather than being routed back to compose-post.
3) Pod status shows Restart Count: 0 and Ready=True, so there is no crash/restart loop that would indicate recursive self-invocation caused by misconfiguration.
Conclusion: Root cause for the errors is an unreachable post-storage-service (down or refusing connections), not a misconfigured callback/Thrift client causing circular RPC.

Testable checks (two-sided where applicable): 1) kubectl describe/deployment for compose-post-service: inspect environment variables, configmaps, and command-line args for downstream hostnames/Thrift endpoints (look for entries referencing user-mention-service, url-shorten-service or any compose-post hostname). 2) kubectl logs (recent slow traces request-ids) from compose-post pods (post-storage-service list available) to confirm outgoing calls and whether the final return is routed back into compose-post. 3) Verify compose-post's Thrift client config (in pod filesystem or configmap) for callback URLs and timeouts. 4) Check compose-post pod CPU/memory and restart counts to rule out crash/restart loops. Relevant data deps: post-storage-service-5f4d46cbb9-8b98m, unique-id-service-fc74bdf74-v6shv, media-service-8486767bd-hx7ln, text-service-774b6cf48f-pfgwf, user-timeline-service-647bd67bfb-mfxdv, home-timeline-service-6bf55fbcd8-vkls2, user-service-5cf866746f-ck27p.

insights: Deployment compose-post-service is running with 1 replica and mounts a ConfigMap (compose-post-service) providing service-config.json and jaeger-config.yml; there are no environment variables overriding endpoints.

service-config.json contains explicit downstream service addresses (e.g., post-storage-service, user-mention-service, url-shorten-service) and also includes a compose-post-service entry (a normal self-entry), so there is no obvious misconfiguration pointing downstream clients back to the pod itself.
The compose-post pod (compose-post-service-7b495f794-t2t8w) is Running and Ready with Restart Count = 0, indicating no crash/restart loop or self-recursion symptom.

Pod logs contain repeated Thrift TSocket connection failures: numerous 'Connection refused' errors when attempting to connect to post-storage-service:9090 and repeated 'Failed to connect post-storage-client' client-pool errors.

Correlation of the ConfigMap (expected downstream hostnames) with the pod logs shows outgoing calls target post-storage-service and fail with connection refused — the failures originate from an unreachable/refusing downstream (post-storage-service), not from requests looping back to compose-post-service.
Confirmed hypothesis: compose-post-service is not misconfigured to call itself (circular RPC) — that hypothesis is disproven.

Root cause: post-storage-service is unreachable or refusing connections on port 9090, causing compose-post-service Thrift client failures (connection refused) and the observed error messages in compose-post logs.

args.diagnosis: compose-post-service is NOT participating in a circular RPC. Its configuration (service-config.json) correctly references downstream hostnames (user-mention-service, url-shorten-service, post-storage-service) and includes a self-entry for compose-post-service (expected). The observed errors are caused by post-storage-service being unreachable (Thrift connection refused), not by requests looping back into compose-post-service.
args.reasoning:
1) ConfigMap (compose-post-service/service-config.json) shows downstream endpoints correctly set (e.g., "user-mention-service": {"addr": "user-mention-service"}, "url-shorten-service": {"addr": "url-shorten-service"}, and a self-entry for "compose-post-service" which is normal).
2) Pod logs from compose-post-service consistently show Thrift TSocket connect() failures to post-storage-service:9090 with "Connection refused" and client pool errors — indicating outgoing calls fail at that downstream service rather than being routed back to compose-post.
3) Pod status shows Restart Count: 0 and Ready=True, so there is no crash/restart loop that would indicate recursive self-invocation caused by misconfiguration.
Conclusion: Root cause for the errors is an unreachable post-storage-service (down or refusing connections), not a misconfigured callback/Thrift client causing circular RPC.

rca_analyses_list.reasoning:
Evidence:
1) compose-post ConfigMap (service-config.json) shows user-mention-service configured as {"addr": "user-mention-service", "port": 9090} — exact host and port used by compose-post.
2) Kubernetes Service user-mention-service exists in namespace test-social-network with spec.ports[0].port=9090 and targetPort=9090 and selector service=user-mention-service — this matches the compose-post setting.
3) user-mention Deployment mounts a ConfigMap that includes a compose-post-service entry (addr: "compose-post-service", port: 9090) — config contains a reference back to compose-post, but this is a static configuration entry (not by itself proof of an active callback).
4) compose-post logs show repeated Thrift connection refusals to post-storage-service:9090, not to user-mention; user-mention logs show only startup info and no incoming-request entries. Therefore there is no runtime evidence of compose-post calling user-mention failing, nor of user-mention calling back into compose-post.
Conclusion: The original hypothesis (misconfigured endpoint or callback causing a round-trip) is not supported by the collected data. The observed connectivity errors are with post-storage-service and should be investigated separately.

1) compose-post ConfigMap (service-config.json) shows user-mention-service configured as {"addr": "user-mention-service", "port": 9090} — exact host and port used by compose-post.
2) Kubernetes Service user-mention-service exists in namespace test-social-network with spec.ports[0].port=9090 and targetPort=9090 and selector service=user-mention-service — this matches the compose-post setting.
3) user-mention Deployment mounts a ConfigMap that includes a compose-post-service entry (addr: "compose-post-service", port: 9090) — config contains a reference back to compose-post, but this is a static configuration entry (not by itself proof of an active callback).
4) compose-post logs show repeated Thrift connection refusals to post-storage-service:9090, not to user-mention; user-mention logs show only startup info and no incoming-request entries. Therefore there is no runtime evidence of compose-post calling user-mention failing, nor of user-mention calling back into compose-post.
Conclusion: The original hypothesis (misconfigured endpoint or callback causing a round-trip) is not supported by the collected data. The observed connectivity errors are with post-storage-service and should be investigated separately.

message_history.content: Final diagnosis submitted successfully. Investigation complete.

final_report.root_cause: post-storage-service was not accepting Thrift connections on port 9090 (connection refused) during the incident window. compose-post-service Thrift clients repeatedly failed with TSocket connect() "Connection refused" errors when attempting to contact post-storage-service:9090. Those storage failures caused compose-post to fail/retry the post-persist flow, which manifested as repeated downstream invocations (user-mention and url-shorten) and the circular-looking traces. No misconfiguration or runtime circular RPC was found in compose-post or user-mention that would explain the observed behavior; the proximate cause is the unreachability/refusal of post-storage-service.
final_report.evidence_summary: 1) All slow traces contained has_error=true and showed repeated alternation among compose-post -> user-mention -> url-shorten, but trace error_message fields are empty (symptom). 2) compose-post Service config (service-config.json) correctly references downstream hostnames (user-mention-service, url-shorten-service, post-storage-service) and includes a normal self-entry. 3) compose-post pod logs (compose-post-service-7b495f794-t2t8w) show repeated Thrift TSocket connect() failures to post-storage-service:9090 with "Connection refused" and client-pool errors. 4) compose-post pod is Running and Ready with Restart Count = 0 (no crash/restart loop). 5) user-mention service and deployment configuration match compose-post's configured endpoint and user-mention pod logs show only startup info (no evidence of runtime callbacks into compose-post). 6) Correlation of config, logs, and traces indicates the immediate failure is an unreachable/connection-refusing post-storage-service, and the repeated downstream calls are a consequence (retries/failure propagation), not a misrouted circular RPC originating from compose-post.
final_report.investigation_summary: Priority-weighted investigation steps completed: (1) Epicenter/config check for compose-post (priority #1): inspected compose-post deployment, ConfigMap (service-config.json) and pod logs; determined compose-post is correctly configured and observed connection refused errors targeting post-storage-service:9090. (2) Connection/config check compose-post <-> user-mention (priority #2): verified service/port alignment, checked user-mention deployment/config and logs; no runtime evidence of user-mention calling back into compose-post. Tools used: kubectl describe/get, get logs, ConfigMap inspection, trace correlation. Findings from these high-priority tasks consistently point to post-storage-service being unreachable as the proximate fault. Lower-priority tasks (detailed checks of url-shorten, user-mention idempotency, infra for url-shorten, and a full post-storage investigation) were planned but are not required to localize the root cause to post-storage-service refusing connections. Recommended operational next steps (not required to conclude RCA): inspect post-storage-service pods and service endpoints, check post-storage process logs, container status, listen ports, readiness/liveness probes, and any recent deployments/rollouts or node/network events during the incident window to determine why it was refusing connections.

prompts_config.triage_agent:
You are an expert Site Reliability Engineer. Your mission is to triage a Kubernetes application by analyzing the provided data.

Your analysis must adhere to the following rules:
1.  **Focus**: Identify symptoms at the **pod or service level only**. Do not provide cluster-wide analysis or generalizations.
2.  **Aggregation**: For each pod or service that has issues, create **at most one symptom entry**. Aggregate all related evidence (from pods, metrics, traces) into that single entry.
3.  **Action**: Synthesize the information to identify and list potential symptoms. For each symptom, pinpoint the affected resource (pod or service) and cite the specific evidence.
4.  **Resource Naming**: In the `affected_resource` field, provide ONLY the exact resource name without any decorators, prefixes, or namespace qualifiers (e.g., use "geo-6b4b89b5f5-rsrh7" NOT "test-hotel-reservation/geo-6b4b89b5f5-rsrh7").
5.  **Trace-Only Evidence**: If error traces are the only signals, still produce symptoms by identifying the service (or pod) that owns the failing span and summarizing the suspected issue using the trace error message. Avoid generic "trace failed" statements—make the hypothesis explicit (e.g., "checkout-service may have invalid credentials because trace X shows `401 Unauthorized` calling payment-service").
6.  **Empty State**: If the provided data contains no issues, it is correct to return an empty list of symptoms.
prompts_config.planner_agent:
You are an expert Site Reliability Engineer. Produce a concise, de-duplicated investigation plan where each task inspects a precise part of the infrastructure to surface the most likely root-cause signals and converge on the true RCA quickly.

**Planning Rules**
1. For every symptom, classify the dominant failure domain (app, latency, dependency/config, or platform) and craft a single, testable hypothesis per resource.
2. Use the `data_dependencies` and `infra_dependencies` JSON to ground every hypothesis. Merge overlapping symptoms into one task per resource.
3. **Connections (non-negotiable):** Always create at least one task that inspects the connection between every pair of affected resources or the epicenter and its downstream dependents. These tasks must perform explicit two-sided checks (e.g., verify `service-a`'s config for `service-b`'s URL **and** inspect `service-b`'s Kubernetes service definition for the matching port/name) to catch login/URL/port misconfigurations.

**Tool Selection**
You are obligated to fill the field with "the smallest set of tools required to accomplish the task"

**Priority Policy**
- Assign unique priorities (1..N).
- Priority 1 is the most direct epicenter investigation. Immediately after that, schedule the connection-check tasks described above; treat them as top-tier because they frequently surface misconfigurations.
- Remaining priorities should rank other high-impact hypotheses (shared dependencies, severe crashes) ahead of narrow or low-scope checks.
prompts_config.rca_agent:
You are an expert DevOps engineer performing focused Root Cause Analysis on a Kubernetes service.

Instructions:
1. You have full autonomy to select the necessary tools from the toolkit. Decide which tools are required to verify your hypotheses efficiently.
2. For each tool call, first formulate a clear, testable hypothesis about a possible root cause that can be answered by the result. Avoid broad or exploratory queries.
3. Each tool call must provide unique, non-overlapping information. Never repeat requests with similar parameters or investigate the same aspect repeatedly in slightly different ways.
4. Stop investigating, even if you have not reached the budget limit, when you have:
   - Clear evidence that directly identifies a root cause (or definitively rules one out)
   - Multiple data points indicating the same failure/cause
   - Sufficient information to answer the investigation goal
5. DO NOT:
   - Repeat or re-run tools unless you are testing a truly new and justified hypothesis
   - Investigate unrelated resources or expand scope beyond the investigation goal
6. When you have gathered sufficient, non-redundant evidence (typically after 2-3 targeted tool calls), call submit_final_diagnosis with:
   - diagnosis: State the precise root cause as it pertains to the investigation goal
   - reasoning: Support your diagnosis by referencing unique findings from your tool calls

REMEMBER: Quality over quantity. Focus on unique and conclusive findings rather than exhaustive or repetitive investigation
prompts_config.supervisor_agent:
You are an expert Site Reliability Engineer analyzing RCA findings to determine the root cause of an incident.

Analyze all symptoms and investigation findings to:
1. Identify patterns and correlations across findings
2. Determine the primary root cause
3. List all affected resources
4. Summarize key evidence

**Understanding Task Priority:**
Each RCA investigation task has been assigned a priority level:
- Priority 1 = Most important / Most likely to reveal root cause (investigated first)
- Priority 2, 3, ... = Progressively lower importance
- Tasks with lower priority numbers should generally have higher weight in your analysis
- The priority reflects the likelihood that investigating that task/resource would uncover the root cause

Use the priority information to contextualize findings: results from priority 1 tasks are typically more significant for determining root cause than lower priority investigations.

**Detection & Localization Requirements:**
- **detection**: Set to `true` if any problem/anomaly was detected in the cluster based on the evidence. Set to `false` only if no issues are found.
- **localization**: Provide a list of ONLY the faulty/problematic components (service names or pod names) directly identified as the root cause. This should be a minimal, precise list - extract ONLY the specific resource(s) that caused the incident, not all affected resources.
  - Example: If a service "user-service" has a misconfiguration causing downstream failures, localization = ["user-service"]
  - Example: If a pod "database-pod-xyz" is failing, localization = ["database-pod-xyz"]
  - Leave empty/null if the root cause cannot be localized to a specific service or pod.

**Root Cause Expectations:**
- Build a causal chain that connects symptoms, investigation evidence, and the precise failure mechanism
- Cite concrete configuration or runtime details (e.g., "service expects port 5432 but database listens on 5433") when diagnosing misconfigurations or integration issues
- If evidence stops at the symptom level, identify the missing proof and pursue it before finalizing

**Strict Iteration Policy:**
Only request another RCA iteration when the existing evidence is insufficient to produce a confident final diagnosis. Never re-run or re-request tasks already marked as completed or currently in progress. When additional work is unavoidable, list only the minimal set of pending task priorities in `tasks_to_be_executed` and clearly justify why each is required. If the current findings support a solid root cause, leave `tasks_to_be_executed` empty and finalize the report.

When you need more evidence, ask for the most targeted pending tasks that can close the causal gap (for example, verifying port mappings, credentials, or configuration values at both ends of a failing connection).

Provide a clear, specific root cause statement that explains what caused the incident and why it happened now.

evaluation.rca_motivation: The agent correctly identifies the right component (post-storage-service) and the key symptom (connection refused/unreachable on port 9090 leading to downstream failures). However, it stops at “unreachability/refusal” and does not identify the specific mechanical root cause from the injection (Service misconfigured targetPort 9999 vs app listening on 9090). Thus it captures the effect but not the exact configuration error.
